question: Does deamination of cytidine to uridine on the minus strand of retroviral DNA during reverse transcription induce G-to-A hypermutation that inactivates the viral genome? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Here, we demonstrate that it does, as APOBEC3G exerts its antiviral effect during reverse transcription to trigger G-to-A hypermutation in the nascent retroviral DNA.
content.source_2: In contrast, high-throughput sequencing of reverse transcripts indicated that APOBEC3G edits only the positive-strand DNA and produces predominantly C-to-T transitions, with no enrichment of G-to-A mutations and no measurable loss of viral infectivity.
content.source_3: APOBEC3G catalyzes cytidine-to-uridine deamination on the minus-strand cDNA during reverse transcription, generating clustered G-to-A substitutions on the coding strand that abrogate viral replication.
content.source_4: Antiviral assays with a catalytically inactive APOBEC3G mutant showed unchanged infectivity and mutational spectra indistinguishable from controls, arguing that deamination does not drive genome inactivation through G-to-A changes.
